The Related Discourses

13. The Noble Path

25. Wrong and Right

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “You must be free of wrong view; you must stop wrong view. If wrong view could not be stopped, then I would not say that you must be free of and stop wrong view. It’s because wrong view can be stopped that I say a monk must be free of wrong view. If he isn’t free of wrong view, then wrong view will make him aimless, disadvantaged, and suffer. Therefore, I say you must be free of wrong view. Thus is wrong intention, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration also explained.

“Monks, after you’re free of wrong view, you must cultivate right view. If it weren’t possible to cultivate right view, I wouldn’t say that you must cultivate right view. It’s because right view can be cultivated that I say a monk must cultivate right view. If he doesn’t cultivate right view, it will make him aimless, disadvantaged, and suffer. Because not cultivating right view makes him aimless, disadvantaged, and suffer, I therefore say he must cultivate right view in order to be purposeful, advantaged, and always happy. Therefore, monks, you must cultivate right view. Thus is right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration also explained.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. A possible Pali parallel is SN 45.21, but this sutra is more elaborate than the Pali’s simple listing of the factors of the wrong and right path.
Translator: Charles Patton
